column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2021-12-02 21:25:12+00:00; ;1466518837696901124;en;217;0;2;11;Twitter Web App;"Pessimism is expecting the worst. This is another step ahead; you're imagining yourself in that situation and evoking the feelings you'd feel
column2: as if it was happening for real."

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2021-12-02 21:22:21+00:00; ;1466518123243315204;en;303;0;3;21;Twitter Web App;It can be quite unhealthy on the long run
column2: since you're feeling those situations as real
column3: and it keeps your mind in a frequent state of emotional distress. It's probably a response to trauma
column4: trying to anticipate future situations where extreme unmanageable feelings might arise.

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2021-12-02 21:19:09+00:00; ;1466517314728341508;en;855;13;14;102;Twitter Web App;"Imagining worst case scenario serves a purpose; self-provoking the negative feelings that might arise
column2: so you're ready to face them in case it happens for real. If it catches you unprepared
column3: those feelings will knock you off your feet and you'll have no tools to manage them."

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2021-09-15 15:28:24+00:00; ;1438162793329479686;en;2;0;1;0;Twitter Web App;"@dreamsofskies Some are motor
column3: sensitive
column4: parasympathetic... there's a bit of everything. They mostly innervate the face and the neck area. The Accessory (XI) is the motor nerve for the the Sternocleidomastoid and the trapezius.

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column2: they originate in the brain stem (their nucleus are there) and exit the brain through the floor of the cranial cavity without crossing the spine. There's 12 of them
column3: some more known

column2: many of the nerves involved in the upper airway don't originate in the spine (like most of the other ones)
column3: but directly on the brain and then go down (cranial nerves)

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2021-08-06 07:18:53+00:00; ;1423544087769227265;en;3;0;1;0;Twitter Web App;@LilLeftofNormal There's a strong link between CFS/ME and POTS (80% have it)
column2: and they recently found a SPN (single nucleotide polymorphism) in the gene of the alpha 1A adrenergic receptor in this group of patients
column3: directly tied to the regulation of vasodilation and negative adrenergic feedback

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2021-08-06 07:16:51+00:00; ;1423543575757864961;en;3;0;1;0;Twitter Web App;@LilLeftofNormal Anxiety and trauma cause a hyperalert state
column2: that perpetuated in time will trigger an exaggerated adrenergic response by the smallest stimuli
column3: like a change in blood volume caused by standing. If this is predominant over vasodilation you'll have hyperadrenergic POTS

column2: so some people self medicate with caffeine. Some people with ADHD get sleepy when drinking it

column2: so they don't understand it and call us lazy. It's very stigmatizing and can destroy your self esteem and mental health. You're led to believe that if you really wanted to

column2: I think what most affects me is that I can get distracted easily if I get more than one stimulus at the same time
column3: and that also reflects on how I act around others. I forget you can multitask
column4: sometimes. Distractibility is probably the most prominent trait.

column2: but it's true. I have no issues with my body for myself
column3: they all came from social expectations of what I should look like and how ashamed I should be of being fat. I find all bodies beautiful
column4: why shouldn't I give myself that love too?

column3: well

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2021-05-01 12:34:50+00:00; ;1388471976822517769;en;21;0;1;0;Twitter Web App;@AdultingADHD @oscarkh29 @AdhdAngsty -the same way being just gay doesn't turn you into one. column2: make a thorough evaluation and pinpoint the most impairing items.

column1: Younger people usually struggle more with core traits. Measures should be directed at helping them deal in a healthy way and preventing them from having debilitating consequences on the long run. 7/"

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column2: pay attention to coping mechanisms and mental health issues. Anxiety is a common coping mechanism
column3: which can be detrimental on the long run. Depression and (c)PTSD are common. These will shape the kind of support they need
column4: even if they don't fit the diagnostic criteria 6/

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column2: make a thorough assessment. Many neurodivergent people have more than more condition at the same time. Some might be diagnosed with dyslexia
column3: but also have undiagnosed ADHD
column6: etc. When they co-occur they can camouflage each other and be harder to spot. 5/

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column2: what should we assess in someone in order to give them the support they need?
listen to several people with the same disabilities to know what are the most common struggles
column3: and what support has been helpful to them. Learn as much as you can. 4/"

column2: or be deemed problematic. This is why disability should always be addressed as an intersectional issue. 3/

column4: if any of them is still present

column6: but often forever since it might become a trigger for dissociation in the future. It depends on the person).

column2: you have alexythimia (no words for feelings). You essentially cannot identify what you're feeling. It's more common in autistic people.

column3: and we don't know what they are."

column1: So the question here is what factors make emotions suck for us. In ADHD
column2: the neural pathway between the prefrontal cortex (the boss) and the limbic system (where feelings originate)
column3: isn't working properly. So our feelings are biochemically ""normal"" -"

column3: i don't mind if I'm slow. Finishing is not the goal.

column1: Power of will discourse is toxic

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2021-04-09 21:49:14+00:00; ;1380638961689894912;en;1235;3;2;109;Twitter Web App;As long as that discourse exists
column2: many disabled people will fall into that endless cycle of shame and distress. It takes years
column3: luck and perseverance to understand yourself and stop buying into it. And even then
column4: that guilt is ingrained and resurfaces to make you doubt yourself.

column2: causing self esteem issues and affecting their mental health. Without knowing why
column3: not understanding what's wrong with them

column2: you only get an ADHD diagnosis if those symptoms are impairing. THE FUCK? Those coping mechanisms are incredibly exhausting and tax us a lot

column2: anxiety often isn't a secondary issue. It's a needed coping mechanism that might become pathological on the long run
column3: specially when ADHD goes unnoticed. That's why an early diagnosis is so important
column4: to get help before debilitating anxiety and dissociation happen.

column2: anxious ADHDers reach a breaking point where they can't cope with the distress
column3: and a new coping mechanism might arise: dissociation. The brain tries to protect itself from the overwhelming distress by shutting down
column4: often triggered by overlapping emotional distress.

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column3: also cause high levels of distress. Added to a high baseline of anxiety
column6: it often causes mental health issues. Depressive and dissociative symptoms are very common.

column1: I have two types (?). One is when I know what I wanna say but it's all conceptual in my brain and it does not translate to actual words. The other (usually when I'm super exhausted) is when I blank out. Mind just doesn't have anything stored that makes sense."

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-10-23 09:59:22+00:00; ;1319579159304306688;en;3;0;2;0;Twitter Web App;@mydyspraxia @autistic_aurora @barisanhantu It took me forever to reach a point where I could sleep well-ish. Sleeping with someone else is the worst

column3: even asleep.

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-10-23 09:57:14+00:00; ;1319578623016341504;en;4;0;2;0;Twitter Web App;@mydyspraxia @autistic_aurora @barisanhantu Same! Anyone walking down the hallway wakes me up
column2: the elevator too. I sleep with earplugs + a headband with wave sound (not ideal but better than the awful tinnitus). Clonidine knocks me out for a few hours
column3: which helps. Also I don't wake up to minimal sounds when I'm on it.

column2: for the millionth time in my life
column3: I'm not one of the cool kids.

column2: I don't feel like a failure for it. I just feel like I can be myself
column3: and people who appreciate it are the ones sticking around. And those are the ones I want to hang out with."
any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-10-18 20:26:42+00:00; ;1317925092228096000;en;52;0;1;0;Twitter Web App;One of my main traits is that I like taking complex ideas and feelings and make them accesible and easier to understand. Because I felt so alone and misunderstood for so long I want to try and make people not feel like that. That's my motivation.

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column2: I often felt like I could do much more
column3: have a more elaborate discourse. But at some point I realized that... all kinds of visibility
column4: as long as it's intersectional and respectful
column5: it's okay. We all have our rhythms and style. We learn at different paces.

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column2: most of them were likely neurodivergent too. But the way we experienced our neurodiversity was different.

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-10-18 20:15:54+00:00; ;1317922375921532933;en;27;1;1;0;Twitter Web App;There were more things
column2: and most of them can be traced back to me being autistic and having ADHD and in general neurodiversity affecting how I experienced life
column3: gender
column4: sexuality... most of the things I was excluded for were rooted in this.

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column2: they were against ableism and we had some conversations about autism and many about ableism. And yet I can't get over the irony that the excluded me... because they were ableist (unknown to all of us at the time).

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-10-18 20:14:21+00:00; ;1317921982403481600;en;22;0;1;0;Twitter Web App;There are many more reasons why some people can't go vegan/vegatarian. That was mine. And at every turn I felt like I was defective and that id everyone could

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-10-18 20:10:07+00:00; ;1317920919243886594;en;34;0;2;0;Twitter Web App;"""You can be a vegetarian if you really try
column2: it's because you don't want to"". No
column3: I cannot. I felt guilt tripped and like shit for years. I even spent many meals with my vegan friends eating stuff that made me wanna puke and suffer (when there was no sensory-friendly alternative)."
any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-10-18 20:07:14+00:00; ;1317920193360891905;en;40;0;2;0;Twitter Web App;The main reason I could not
column2: and will probably never be a vegetarian
column3: is because I have sensory hypersensitivity with food. Most veggies are a no go for me. I also have ADHD
column4: cooking a decent meal is a challenge. So being neurodivergent is a big part of what stopped me from it.

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-10-07 09:27:49+00:00; ;1313773013339381761;en;92;0;1;2;Twitter Web App;So I started bringing lunch to work as often as I could. It really improved my irritability when I was running late
column2: which not only made my driving more safe
column3: but it also made me less snappy and nicer to be around. Right now I'm the most chill at my work about running late.

column2: what made me impatient on my way back? Not being able to leave on time has always been frustrating for me (because I depend on other people's work). Once I learned to accept that
column3: I realized being hungry made me the most impatient. I wanted to rush back home to eat!

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-10-05 21:07:35+00:00; ;1313224338934505472;en;4;0;1;1;Twitter Web App;@Astrenome Accountability: someone external that will make you accountable for stuff you need to do. ADHD affects internal motivation
column2: so relying on an external source helps. Try studying in a library with someone
column3: for example. Ask them to check notes every hour
column4: so you have to keep up.

column2: the less exhausted you'll be. It's not always possible
column3: but specially during exams try and lessen that pressure. If you live with someone
column4: use the structure they provide and follow it as much as you can.

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-10-05 08:32:06+00:00; ;1313034213466267649;en;220;0;5;14;Twitter Web App;In cases of detrimental stress
column2: ask yourself... Can someone else do it? Is it really that important? Is there another way around it? We are capable of many things
column3: but adding tasks that might not be necessary will drain us and we'll be left without energy for other stuff.
any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-10-05 08:29:22+00:00; ;1313033526149812224;en;208;0;1;15;Twitter Web App;Each ADHDer might react in a different way
column2: but trying to find a balance between relieving that guilt and stress while keeping the task at focus is key. From there
column3: try working out what each individual needs to carry out that ask most efficiently.
any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column2: what works then? Try to ease the pressure and guilt while conveying that the task is still there. Try finding out if there was something on the way of them doing it. Try setting a deadline system that will work for them (some people get stressed by them
column3: others don't).
any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-10-05 08:20:27+00:00; ;1313031283778433026;en;256;0;1;16;Twitter Web App;If you take the opposite approach and try and lessen the pressure by making it look like the task is optional
column2: it will relieve that anxiety and guilt... but we will likely not do the task. Making things look optional takes away that urgency/external pressure factor.

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-10-05 08:17:29+00:00; ;1313030536965828608;en;359;2;2;31;Twitter Web App;We've been scolded our whole lives for it. Feeling guilty is a form of external pressure
column2: and you might get an ADHDer to do stuff by guilt tripping them. But it's also very unhealthy. It will likely cause low self esteem
column3: anxiety
column5: and it's detrimental on the long run.

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-10-05 08:13:29+00:00; ;1313029530458771456;en;483;0;2;53;Twitter Web App;Since our internal motivation is affected by ADHD
column2: we often need external pressure and deadlines to work more efficiently. But understanding that this isn't us being childish or irresponsible is important. We are the first ones who get frustrated at not being able to do things.

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-10-05 08:10:26+00:00; ;1313028763865804800;en;1550;23;21;330;Twitter Web App;When interacting with an ADHDer about a task
column2: it's important to realize what you're conveying with your words. If you're too stern and guilt trip
column3: you'll achieve your goal but cause a lot of stress and guilt on the long run. If you make it look optional

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-09-17 19:15:30+00:00; ;1306673151846252549;en;227;1;1;6;Twitter Web App;I know that wasn't the expected answer
column2: but my truth is that I compensate a lot and I destroy myself by doing so. And I can't stop compensating
column3: it's survival. That doesn't mean ADHD doesn't have direct consequences on me
column4: it also does. But that other part is often overlooked.

column2: just listening at first gives you an impression on how well they explain themselves
column3: what their methods are... it's useful.

column1: One of the questions that threw me off the most was ""how much does ADHD affect you?"" Which I knew was a critical question. And yet I struggled."

column3: some even require to call their psych. Try and make this process as accessible and automatic as possible.
any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-08-27 21:16:31+00:00; ;1299093460314714113;en;9;0;1;0;Twitter Web App;Provide free resources. Articles and various links might help people with self discovery and self management. Promote content by people with ADHD.

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-08-27 21:15:46+00:00; ;1299093270480510980;en;17;1;1;1;Twitter Web App;ADHDers sometimes process information externally
column2: so questions often arise after the appointments. Encourage emails to ensure they feel comfortable reaching out with any doubts they might have thought of afterwards.

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column2: encourage ADHDers to note down and/or set reminders themselves for future appointments before they leave consultation. Give information in both oral and written form. Make sure they know what the next step is and answer any questions they might have.

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-08-27 21:11:59+00:00; ;1299092318037905414;en;70;0;1;3;Twitter Web App;Add adress and pinned location in the reminder. Consider which appointments can be telephonic for people using mobility aids
column3: immunocompromised
column4: etc. Ensure accessibility to the appointment site for wheelchair users and notify it on the website.

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-08-27 21:11:17+00:00; ;1299092142200172544;en;82;0;2;3;Twitter Web App;Send reminders. Between second guessing and forgetfulness
column3: many ADHDers might miss an appointment. Reminders should be sent and an appointment confirmation reply encouraged. Offer them to call the day of the appointment
any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-08-27 21:09:53+00:00; ;1299091789098483718;en;79;0;1;5;Twitter Web App;Make sure they submit enough information to potentially reach out (if they're comfortable with it). Some ADHDers might reach out in a moment of panic/hyperfocus
column2: then lose momentum and avoid it. Checking in without being intrusive (email/text) might encourage them.

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS
but also follow-ups. Allow for free date/hour changes. Many people have issues with phone calls. Make it accessible! Phone calls
column4: emails and online forms. Whatever suits each individual.

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column2: a more accessible approach would require more people trained to do so (ie. GPs in coordination with mental health professionals)
column3: since multidisciplinary units are often few and far away
any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-08-27 21:05:09+00:00; ;1299090597438017536;en;97;1;1;5;Twitter Web App;Multidisciplinary units. Having to attend different places for diagnosis/treatment can make people with ADHD not follow through. Also
column2: mental health issues are common so a team assessing the particular struggles of each individual should be standard procedure.

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-08-27 21:04:11+00:00; ;1299090357976784897;en;132;2;4;5;Twitter Web App;Facilitate all the information for each step of the process. Waiting list time
column3: type of tests
column4: family attendance... anything relevant . Try to avoid uncertainty (a struggle for many neurodivergent people
column5: specially if co-occurring anxiety and/or autism).

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-08-23 15:55:41+00:00; ;1297563166457638916;en;4;0;2;0;Twitter Web App;@voltron42 @Finnattentive @SNeurotypicals @danidonovan @ADHD_Alien @elisekumar @3TrackMind79 The more exposed you are to the stressors

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-08-23 15:36:07+00:00; ;1297558242143469568;en;4;1;1;0;Twitter Web App;@voltron42 @Finnattentive @SNeurotypicals @danidonovan @ADHD_Alien @elisekumar @3TrackMind79 My take on it: in ADHD the connections between the prefrontal cortex and some subcortical structures are weakened

column3: and thus chronically activates the stress response on our brain-

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-08-10 14:55:53+00:00; ;1292837077919371266;en;1810;49;58;311;Twitter Web App;People used to call me pessimistic because I always thought of the worst case scenario in every situation. It turns out it's anticipated rejection: If I see it coming
column2: it hurts less if it becomes true. It's a coping mechanism for Rejection Sensitive Dysphoria.

column3: any pronouns. Alt text provided. POTS

column1: Pp @hellosunnycore";10045;Paciente;TEA;TDAH;nan;2020-08-10 07:52:29+00:00; ;1292730526504226817;en;683;3;6;111;Twitter Web App;@on_bicycle There's a neurobiological explanation as to why we feel everything so heightened and can't filter emotions
column2: but the anticipation of rejection does seem to be a trauma response (been hurt before
column3: now terrified of it again). It's a bit of a mix
column4: probably. Just my take on it.
